research experience.summary: Graduate astronomy student researcher studying compact object binaries through gravitational-wave analysis with the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) Scientific Collaboration (LSC); advised by Dr. Carl-Johan Haster.

research experience.name: Glikman Lab (Remote) & Masters Galaxy Group, Haverford College, Haverford, PA, USA
research experience.summary: Conducted my undergraduate senior thesis using a  radio, infrared, and optically selected sample of blue quasars to put dust-reddened red quasars in context. We found a radio-selection dependency and the fraction of red quasars to be 32% in order to complete the UKFS and W2M surveys; advised by Dr. Eilat Glikman & Dr. Karen Masters.

research experience.summary: Studied a candidate dual quasar system using Hubble Space Telescope data and completed a spectroscopic analysis of the closely separated sources with StisTools and found the possible QSO system links dust-reddening to galaxy and black hole mergers; advised by Dr. Eilat Glikman

research experience.name: Masters Galaxy Group, Haverford College, Haverford, PA, USA
research experience.summary: Researched various intrinsic parameters of galactic bars using SDSS MaNGA data, including bar length and position angle, to complete a population comparison analysis, and participated in weekly group journal presentations; advised by Dr. Karen Masters

research experience.summary: Investigated galaxy kinematics and bar formation, performed elliptical isophote analysis with Photutils on MaNGA galaxies. publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).
